details.title: Local Polynomial Fitting in Failure Rate Estimation

p: Dimitrios Bagkavos received his B.Sc. (Hons.) from the Department of Mathematics, University of Ioannina, Greece in 1997; and his Ph.D. in Statistics from the University of Birmingham, U.K. in 2003. Currently, he is working as a consultant at Accenture, Athens, Greece. His research interests include kernel-based estimation of the hazard rate and survival functions, transformation based methods, and analysis of duration data.

Prakash N. Patil received his Ph.D. in Statistics from the University of North Carolina, Chapel Hill, USA in 1990; and currently he is Reader in Statistics at the University of Birmingham, U.K. His research interests include nonparametric smoothing, kernel and wavelet-based methods, and randomized cluster trials.

details.abstract: The failure rate function is one of the most important functions in reliability analysis as it addresses concepts such as scheduling, maintenance, improved system design, cost analysis, etc. Kernel-based estimation of the failure rate function imposes minimal assumptions on the data, and thus offers large flexibility. Therefore, it is very helpful in reliability analysis where the shape of the failure function is a primary target. However, standard kernel estimates are biased more than usual in the endpoints. Motivated by the advantages that the local linear fitting method provides for estimation of densities near the boundary, we employ the technique to the failure rate setting. We show that it produces estimators that have the same amount of boundary bias as in areas outside the boundary. The mean square error properties of the method are demonstrated, and a practically useful procedure for automatic smoothing parameter selection is developed, and studied both theoretically, and by simulations. The result is displayed graphically by distributional, and real life data.

Transformation from availability expression to failure frequency

context.text: For more recent work, see [2]–[5][6].

links.abstract: The problem of computing the system's Failure Frequency is reduced to the problem of computing its Availability. This is performed by a transformation operator. However, the existing transformation operator is not practical because its transformation time increases exponentially with system size. To overcome this difficulty, this paper proposes a new method of transforming the Availability expression of a system into the corresponding Failure Frequency expression of the system. This method is ba...

references.text: M. Hayashi, T. Abe, I. Nakajima, "Transformation from availability expression to failure frequency expression", IEEE Trans. Reliability, vol. 55, no. 2, pp. 252-261, 2006.

references.title:
An effective bandwidth selector for local
least squares regression

context.text: This rule is an extension to the failure rate setting of the method developed in [14], combining at the same time the ideas of [15].
Following [15], we partition the available data \$(x_{i}, Y_{i})\$, \$i=1, \ldots, n\$ into \$N_{1}\$ blocks, and we fit a quartic (i.e. a polynomial of fourth degree) in each block.
with \$RSS(N_{1})\$ being the residual sum of squares of the fit, and \$N_{\max}=\max \{\min(\lfloor n/20\rfloor, N^{\ast}), 1\}\$, where \$N^{\ast}=5\$ (see [15]).

references.text: D. Ruppert, S. J. Sheather, M. P. Wand, "An effective bandwidth selector for local least squares regression", Journal of the American Statistical Association, vol. 90, pp. 1257-1270, 1995.

references.title:
Customer-rush near warranty expiration limit and nonparametric
hazard rate estimation from known mileage accumulation rates

context.text: Similar estimates have been employed by [17] to estimate the failure rate function from known mileage accumulation rates, and from [18] in modeling the failure data of a repairable equipment with bathtub-type failure intensity.

links.abstract: Time or mileage data obtained from warranty claims are generally more accurate for hard failures than for soft failures. For soft failures, automobile users sometimes delay reporting the warranty claim until the warranty coverage is about to expire. This results in an unusually high number of warranty claims near the end of warranty coverage. Because such a phenomenon of customer-rush near the warranty expiration limit occurs due to user behavior rather than due to the vehicle design, it creates...

references.text: B. Rai, N. Singh, "Customer-rush near warranty expiration limit and nonparametric hazard rate estimation from known mileage accumulation rates", IEEE Trans. Reliability, vol. 55, no. 3, pp. 480-489, 2006.

references.title:
Modeling the failure data of a repairable
equipment with bathtub type failure intensity

context.text: Similar estimates have been employed by [17] to estimate the failure rate function from known mileage accumulation rates, and from [18] in modeling the failure data of a repairable equipment with bathtub-type failure intensity.
The original data, which were given in actual observed times, were analyzed also by [29], and [18] using non-homogeneous Poisson processes (NHPP) models.

In [29], it was argued that the log-linear process (LLP) model provides better representation than a power law process (PLP) model, and in [18] it was shown that there is statistically significant evidence of a bathtub type non-monotonic failure intensity in a global context of increasing intensity.

references.text: G. Pulcini, "Modeling the failure data of a repairable equipment with bathtub type failure intensity", Reliability Engineering and System Safety, vol. 71, pp. 209-218, 2001.

references.title: Bias reduction in nonparametric hazard rate estimation

context.text: Then, the standard calculations (see [19], paragraph A.1.1) show that the estimate of the failure function resulting from (1), and (2) is .
Reference [19] shows that, for kernel estimation of the failure rate function, the asymptotically optimal bandwidth which minimizes the mean integrated square error is .

As it was exhibited in [19], in the boundary, this estimate is expected to underestimate the true failure function at approximately half the actual value, unless the true failure function is zero there.

references.text: D. Bagkavos, Bias reduction in nonparametric hazard rate estimation, 2003, The University of Birmingham.

references.title:
Theoretical explanation of observed decreasing
failure rate

context.text: In Fig. 2, we estimate the failure rate for the aircraft dataset of [24] on the basis that such an analysis is interesting for preventive maintenance purposes.
[24] tested the fit of the exponential distribution to these data using the Kolmogorov-Smirnov test of fit, and was unable to reject the hypothesis that the pooled data are exponentially distributed.

references.text: F. Proschan, "Theoretical explanation of observed decreasing failure rate", Technometrics, vol. 5, pp. 375-383, 1963.
